metadata.case_name: Descendants of former ruling chiefs v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellants are descendants of former ruling chiefs in Hoshangabad and Nimar Districts of Madhya Pradesh.
Appellants held estates as Jahgirdars, Maufidars and Ubaridars, enjoying exemption from land revenue amounting to Rs. 27,828-5-0 yearly.
Central Provinces and Berar Revocation of Land Revenue Exemptions Act, 1948 made such exempted lands liable to land revenue from 1948-49.
Appellants applied to Deputy Commissioner under the Act for grant of money or pension as suitable maintenance.
Deputy Commissioner forwarded application to State Government.
State Government rejected petition by order No. 993 XVI-4 dated April 26, 1955, without reasons.
Appellants filed petition under Art. 226 in Madhya Pradesh High Court for writ of certiorari to quash State Government order.
High Court (Full Bench, Chief Justice) held that power under s.5 was discretionary, petition incompetent; dismissed without going into other questions.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court from High Court judgment.
Rules framed under s.8 of Act provide for enquiry by Deputy Commissioner including special enquiries for descendants of ruling chiefs.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of s.5(3) make it obligatory upon State Government to make suitable grant of money or pension to descendant from former ruling chief who lost exemption under the Act.
Whether State Government order rejecting petition without reasons and without hearing appellants was proper.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rejection by State Government without giving reasons amounted to no decision at all and was improper and illegal exercise of power under s.5.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226 of Constitution; s.5 of Act

petitioner_arguments.text: View of High Court on s.5(3) erroneous; section is mandatory notwithstanding language appearing to confer discretion, if conditions fulfilled.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants were not descendants of any former ruling chief.
Exercise of power by State Government proper and legal; powers under Act discretionary, no remedy by writ under Art.226.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of s.5: sub-s.(2) discretionary for general applications, but sub-s.(3) modifies discretion; rules highlight special enquiries for religious institutions/services and descendants of ruling chiefs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'may' in s.5(3) must be interpreted as mandatory when conditions precedent fulfilled, i.e., existence of descendant of former ruling chief.

court_reasoning.text: Government must perform duty under Act in judicial manner, give hearing to claimants in light of Deputy Commissioner report, and provide reasons for rejection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of April 26, 1955 gives no reasons; appellants not heard; Act bars civil suit, so quasi-judicial procedure required.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in holding s.5(3) confers absolute discretion like s.5(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'May' in statutes for public good often compulsory; here obligatory if conditions met.

holdings.text: s.5(3) mandatory: Government must grant money or pension to deserving descendant of former ruling chief if conditions fulfilled.
State Government must act quasi-judicially, provide hearing and reasons when rejecting claims under s.5(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs Hari Nagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sunder Jhunjhunwala & Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons must appear even if order based on confidential material when Government performs quasi-judicial functions.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces and Berar Revocation of Land Revenue Exemptions Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Revokes exemptions (s.3), provides for applications for grants/pensions (s.5 mandatory under s.5(3) for specified cases), bars civil courts (s.6), rules (s.8)

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Land Revenue Act, 1917
statutes_cited.relevance: Amendments by s.4; exemptions possible under s.7 of 1948 Act

statutes_cited.name: Berar Land Revenue Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Applicable to Berar lands; amendments by s.4

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition remedy as suit barred

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held High Court erred in interpreting s.5(3) as discretionary; State Government order invalid for lack of reasons and hearing; matter requires quasi-judicial consideration.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order set aside implicitly; State Government directed to reconsider quasi-judicially

key_quotes.text: The word 'may' in s.5(3) must be interpreted as mandatory when the conditions precedent... is established.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on mandatory nature of s.5(3)

key_quotes.text: The Act lays upon the Government a duty which obviously must be performed in a judicial manner.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Government is bound to make a grant to those who fulfill the required condition and the word 'may'... has to be read as must.
key_quotes.speaker: court
